Lorraine Valentine, 42, suffers from erythropoietic protoporphyria (EPP)<n>Condition is caused by a build-up of a chemical called protoporphyrin in the blood.<n>As blood passes through the skin, protoporphyrin absorbs the energy from sunlight.<n>This sets off a chemical reaction that can damage surrounding tissues.<n>The nerve endings in the skin interpret this as itching or burning pain.<n>EPP is incurable and there is currently no cure.

The revolutionary system is being commercialised by French company Pixium Vision, with clinical trials scheduled for 2016.<n>It is based on a technique known as 'neuromodulation' in which electricity from a chip stimulates the nervous system to restore sight.<n>A surgeon first implants a small silicon chip with 150 electrodes on the retina.<n>When the patient puts on the system's dark glasses, an integrated video camera sends images to a portable computer.<n>A connected 'pocket processor' converts that recording into an infrared image, which the goggles will then beam into the eye.

Calcium formations on ‘Altamura Man’, a skeleton found in a cave in 1993, suggest he was 128,000 to 187,000 years old.<n>Now researchers plan to sequence his DNA to see if they can reveal new details about the evolution of our ancient ancestors.<n>It has been around 30,000 years since the ancestors of modern-day humans are thought to have wiped out the ancient Neanderthals.

The tunnels were dug into sandstone cliffs along the River Mersey in Stockport in the 1930s.<n>They were originally intended to be used as car parking spaces, but the Second World War meant they were needed as air raid shelters.<n>The shelter was so popular that local officials had to issue season tickets limiting the number of people who could seek refuge there.<n>The shelter space is now operated as a museum, and has been restored to how it might have looked to residents hiding there during the war.

Tokyo researchers have proposed a laser system to attach to the ISS.<n>It would be used to shoot down pieces of debris in Earth orbit.<n>The system would have a range of 62 miles (100km) and could target things less than 0.4 inches (1cm) in size.<n>The impact of the laser beam on debris would create a force that reduced its velocity, causing it to fall into Earth’s atmosphere and burn up.<n>Without going into specifics, the team says their proposal could remove ‘most’ of the centimetre-sized debris in Earth orbit within five years of operation.

Astronomers have used a telescope in New Mexico to watch a star take shape over eight years.<n>The star – known as W75N(B)-VLA2 – is 300 times brighter and eight times bigger than our sun.<n>But what has most excited astronomers is the change in shape of the violet area of super-hot electrified winds that are being ejected by the young star.<n>The dramatic changes, in a cosmic blink of an eye relative to the age of the universe, is giving an unprecedented look at how young ‘protostars’ develop into fully-fledged stars.

The Dragon King dinosaur skull is being sold by Hong Kong-based experts Evolve.<n>It is more than 95 per cent complete bone, is 9.2ft (2.8 metres) long, 5.2ft (1.6 metres) high and 4.6ft (1.4 metres) wide.<n>The name of the fossil is inspired by the symbol of'strength, good fortune and longevity' in Chinese culture - the dragon.<n>The last time something of this size and quality came to market was when a Tyrannosaurus Rex fossil named 'Sue' was sold for £5.6 million ($8.5 million) in 1997.

The Caverne du Pont-d'Arc has been built a few miles from the original site in Vallon-Pont-D'arc in Southern France.<n>It contains 1,000 painstakingly-reproduced drawings, as well as around 450 bones and other features.<n>Experts scanned the original drawings using 3D modelling techniques to capture each marking and position them correctly on the bumpy replica walls to the millimetres.<n>Unique representations include a panther, owl and even part of the female body, making the original site an invaluable research subject for scientists around the world.<n>The replica cave will open to the public on April 25

Curiosity detected salts called perchlorates, which can absorb water from the atmosphere and turn it into briny liquid.<n>When night falls, some of the water vapour in the atmosphere condenses on the planet surface as frost, but calcium perchlorate is very absorbent.<n>It forms a brine with the water, so the freezing point is lowered and the frost can turn into a liquid.

The aim was to explore how much nature and nurture influence our party political allegiances and potential voting preferences.<n>Twin studies are useful for exploring whether a trait is forged in the genes, passed down or by the environment a person is living in.<n>As identical twins share exactly the same DNA, traits produced by genes should appear in both twins.<n>But in non-identical twins the DNA will not be the same and so differences can occur.<n>The exception seemed to be voting for the Liberal Democrats, which was affected entirely by environment with no genetic influence.

US researchers claim that exact prices of goods on eBay attract higher offers than round numbers.<n>When the initial price is a round number, such as $1,000, the average counteroffer is between five and eight per cent lower than if it is a non-round number, like $1,079.<n>Sellers who end their price with ‘00’ typically receive offers that are five to eight per cent lower than those with more specific prices.<n>But sellers with round numbers are more likely to close a deal six to 11 days sooner, and are up to 5 per cent more likely to sell at all.

The tracks were found in Ileret, northwest Kenya, in sediment that had once been the shoreline of an ancient lake.<n>They are the oldest human footprints in the world and were discovered in 2009.<n>Analysis of the prints revealed they had been made by a species with a similar bipedal stance and gait to modern humans.<n>They were left by Homo erectus - an extinct species of early human that disappeared around 200,000 years ago.<n>They were among the longest surviving of all the human species - surviving for around 1.5 million years.

German banking giant Deutsche Bank will pay $2.5 billion in fines for its role in a vast multi-year conspiracy to rig LIBOR interest rates.<n>The case centers on charges that Deutsche Bank derivatives traders manipulated the London InterBank Offered Rate, used to peg millions of interest rate-sensitive contracts and loans around the world.<n>Under the deferred prosecution agreement, Deutsche Bank agreed to plead guilty to a US charge of wire fraud, a criminal offense, in connection with the scam and admitted participating in price-fixing conspiracy with other banks.<n>The $2.5 billion fine is a record for interest-rate manipulation.

Neanderthals were the dominant human species in Europe and much of Asia for around 250,000 years before vanishing entirely 41,000 years ago.<n>Scientists took CT scans of teeth found at Riparo Bombrini in western Ligurian Alps and in the Grotta di Fumane in western Lessini Mountains, both in Italy.<n>They found they belonged to ancestors of modern humans who were part of a group known as the Protoaurignacian culture.<n>They suggest it was the arrival of this modern human culture that marked a turning point in humanity’s evolution and led to the rapid disappearance of Neanderthals.

Retired couple Brian and Charlotte Smith have found 102 concrete arrows in the US.<n>The giant arrows were once markers for early airmail flights across the country.<n>By 1929, the arrows could direct flights all the way across the width of America.<n>In the days before radio and satellite communications, the arrows were a way to ensure pilots could find their way.<n>The giant arrows started to be placed across the country, sometimes at 10-mile intervals, from 1924.<n>In the summer of 1924, they stretched from Wyoming to Ohio and by the following year, the arrows had reached New York.

50 earthquake scientists from country the world met in Kathmandu last week.<n>They discussed how the area would cope with such a disaster.<n>'Physically and geologically what happened is exactly what we thought would happen,' said seismologist James Jackson.<n>Earthquakes of similar magnitude can have bigger effects on different parts of the globe because of the manner of building construction and population density.<n>A 7.8 magnitude earthquake could kill 10 to 30 per one million residents in California, but has killed at least 1,900 in Nepal, and could kill up to 10,000 in parts of Pakistan, India, Iran and China

Researchers have combined long-term fisheries data with climate model projections from the Met Office.<n>From this they were able to predict the abundance and distribution of the UK's fish over the next 50 years.<n>As the North Sea warms, species won't be able to migrate north to avoid warming temperatures because habitat of a suitable depth is rare.<n>UK fisheries will need to replace current species with those that prefer warmer water such as red mullet and John dory.

Palaeontologists are referring to Chilesaurus diegosuarezi as a 'platypus' dinosaur because of its bizarre combination of characteristics.<n>These include its small skull and feet, which are more like those seen on long-neck dinosaurs.<n>The animal is proving to be an evolutionary jigsaw puzzle because it belongs to the theropod group of dinosaurs.<n>The presence of herbivorous theropods was up until now only known in close relatives of birds, but Chilesaurus shows that a meat-free diet was acquired much earlier than first thought.

The Planetary Society says Nasa can afford a crewed mission to orbit the Martian moon Phobos in 2033, leading up to a crewed landing on the Red Planet in 2039.<n>It concluded that such a plan could indeed fit within NASA's human space exploration budget - but that politics is holding the decision back.<n>The Phobos orbital mission would last approximately 30 months, with nine months of travel each way and 12 months in orbit.<n>Crewmembers would be able to study Phobos and Deimos, Mars' other moon, and potentially teleoperate rovers on the Martian surface.

The study was conducted by scientists at Purdue University in Indiana.<n>They were investigating how to reduce bird to aircraft collisions by keeping birds away from planes.<n>Research showed that birds responded most to blue lights on planes.<n>Authors suggest runways could be synced with aircraft to alert birds to incoming planes and avoid collisions.<n>And they say their method could even help birds avoid collisions with buildings and wind turbines by also covering them in blue lights.

UK researchers studied the asteroid impact 66 million years ago.<n>They found the heat near the impact site in Mexico was not intense enough to ignite plant material.<n>A heat pulse lasted less than a minute, too short to set plants alight.<n>Further away from the impact site in Mexico, the heat could have lasted up to seven minutes and caused some localised fires.<n>But the theory that a global firestorm accompanied the asteroid impact is not correct, according to the scientists.

Thermal images show copper inside the battery reaching temperatures of at least 1,085C (1,985F) causing jets of molten material to burst from its vent.<n>Footage is the first time the failure of Li-ion batteries due to overheating has been recorded.<n>Li-ion batteries are vulnerable to a condition known as thermal runaway.<n>This occurs when the rate of heat generated in the cell is greater than the rate of heat lost.<n>Authors hope their observations will lead to improvements in the design of Li-ion batteries and improve their safety features.
Photos taken between 1900 and 1911 during the Qing dynasty show Beijing's famous landmarks with barely any visitors.<n>They are some of the earliest holiday snaps of the Chinese capital and show landmarks almost devoid of visitors.<n>The quiet scenes are a far cry from modern-day Beijing, which is one of the most populous cities in the world.

The aluminium battery was created at Stanford University, California.<n>It is the first high-performance aluminium battery that is 'fast-charging, long-lasting and inexpensive', according to its designers.<n>At present the rechargeable aluminium battery generates about two volts of electricity, the highest achieved yet with aluminium.<n>But the researchers said the battery has only half the voltage of lithium-ion technology.

People with rapid eye movement sleep behaviour disorder (RBD) move around in their sleep and 'act out' their dreams.<n>Up to 90 per cent of people with the condition will develop a neurological condition, a study found.<n>RBD affects 0.5 per cent of the population or 35 million people worldwide.<n>It can be managed with high doses of the sleep hormone melatonin or low doses of the anti-anxiety drug clonazepam.

The new dinosaur, named Yi qi, had unusual bristle-like feathers and bat-like wings that were covered in a membrane.<n>Scientists believe the dinosaur, which they have named Yi qi, meaning ‘strange wing’, may have glided or even flown through the air.<n>The fossil was discovered by a local farmer in Mutoudeng, in Qinglong County, Hebei Province in China.<n>It was so well preserved that bristle-like feathers and the remains of its membrane wings could be seen around the bones.

Rachel Simpson, 15, has a one-in-a-million genetic condition which doctors say will eventually give her cancer if untreated.<n>She suffers from a mutation of the GATA2 gene, which is important in the production of blood cells.<n>The disorder means a sufferer's blood count might be low, making them more vulnerable to infection or abnormal blood cells, leading to leukaemia.<n>The rest of her family are now waiting on tests which could reveal which of them also have the faulty gene.

Alfred Taubman, who donated hundreds of millions of dollars to universities, hospitals and museums, died Friday night at his home of a heart attack.<n>Born January 31, 1942, in Pontiac, Michigan, to German-Jewish immigrants, Taubman worked as a boy at a department store after school near his family's home.<n>His business success spanned from real estate and art houses to the hot dog-serving A&W restaurant chain.<n>But it was his rearrangement of how people shop — parking lot in front, several stores in one stop close to home — that left a mark on American culture

Esa’s Rosetta spacecraft has captured stunning images of a dust jet erupting from comet 67P Churyumov-Gerasimenko.<n>The jet is unusual because it is erupting from the dark underside of the comet, whereas such activity had only been seen on the day side so far.<n>In the first image, taken at 7:13am BST (2:13am EST) on 12 March, the upper comet can be seen with several rays of dust illuminated by the sun.<n>Two minutes later, in the second image, a spectacular new jet emerges from the dark side, hurling dust into space

Scientists in The Netherlands were using the Lofar radio telescope.<n>They found it could measure changes in lightning caused by cosmic rays.<n>A storm can have hundreds of millions of volts over multiple kilometres.<n>The method could provide a novel way to understand thunderclouds.<n>Cosmic rays probe the thunderclouds from top to bottom.<n>Moving at almost the speed of light they provide a near instantaneous 'picture' of the electric fields in the cloud.

Bergen-Belsen was the final resting place for 50,000 Jews, Gypsies, homosexuals, Nazi opponents and those with disabilities.<n>It was liberated by British and Canadian troops in 1945 and burned to the ground shortly after.<n>Pictures were taken by Reverend Charles Martin King Parsons, one of a handful of British Army chaplains who entered the camp.

Fire boat Massey Shaw was requisitioned from the London Fire Brigade in 1940 and transported to Dunkirk to help with the evacuation of Allied troops.<n>After carrying 600 soldiers back to Britain, the boat returned to London where it helped to save St Paul's Cathedral and other buildings damaged in the Blitz.<n>The boat went out of service in 1971, and four decades was used as a walkway in a London dock.<n>It took six years to undo the damage wrought on the Massey Shaw and restore it to how it was in the 1930s.

Nasa's Landsat 7 satellite captured the image in the Erg Chech, a desolate sand sea in southwestern Algeria.<n>It shows 'ribbons' of sand and patterned stripes known as linear dunes.<n>But the exact cause of these longitudinal structures is not known.<n>One theory is that linear dunes are created by helical roll vortices.<n>These are long rolls of air that spiral, or rotate one way before rotating another.<n>They are commonly seen in clouds, creating what's known as 'cloud streets' that appear as cumulus-type clouds.

Dr Joe Hanson, a science writer and biologist based in Austin, Texas, has calculated what the human body is in terms of chemical elements.<n>He revealed that a 'human molecule' might contain 375 million atoms of hydrogen, 132 million atoms of oxygen and 85 million atoms of carbon.<n>By comparison, this human molecule contains just one atom of cobalt and three molecules of the metal molybdenum.<n>The average adult human body contains around 16kg (35lbs) of carbon in it and enough oxygen to fill a volume equivalent to 6 elephants.

Palaeontologists at the University of Alberta examined a pair of fossils found in Mongolia, which were first described in 2001.<n>One is a complete skeleton, while the other is missing the middle and end of its tail.<n>They found signs of sexual dimorphism in the length and shape of blade-like bones called chevrons, which point downwards from the vertebrae near the base of the tail.<n>They suggest male oviraptors had broader and longer chevron bones in their tails so they could shake their feather-tipped tail to woo potential mates.

Wegner both documented the suffering they witnessed in images which helped build a case against the Turkish government.<n>As Armenians mark 100 years since the atrocities, many Western countries still do not use that word.<n>Wegner, a volunteer military nurse, set up clandestine mail routes with foreign consulates to get hundreds of notes, annotations, documents, letters and photographs.<n>He did so in defiance of strict orders from the Turkish and German authorities aimed at preventing any evidence of the horrors of the 'genocide' reaching the outside world.

In 84 days from November 2013 to January 2014, the area around Azle, Texas, shook with 27 magnitude two or greater earthquakes.<n>Scientists believe these earthquakes were the result of high-pressure injection of drilling wastewater into the ground.<n>The oil and gas industry uses injection wells to get rid of wastewater, which can have chemicals, heavy metals, salt and radioactive material.

28 fossilised cone snail shells were studied in the Cibao Valley of the northern Dominican Republic.<n>They were exposed to UV light to reveal traces of pigment left in the shells.<n>This allowed scientists to reconstruct shell patterns and colours from millions of years ago.<n>They now believe the shells contain 13 entirely new species of cone snail.

National Grid has revealed the UK's first new pylon for nearly 90 years.<n>Called the T-pylon it is a third shorter than the old lattice pylons.<n>But it is able to carry just as much power - 400,000 volts.<n>It is designed to be less obtrusive and will be used for clean energy.<n>National Grid is building a training line of six T-pylons at their Eakring training academy in Nottinghamshire.<n>They plan to use the first T-pylons with the Hinkley Point C nuclear power station in Somerset.

Scientists at the University of Bristol used a CT scanner to examine the plates.<n>They were found to have different shapes that could have been used to attract a mate.<n>Male stegosaurus may have had the larger, broader plates for use in mating displays while the females may have had the sharper, taller plates.<n>This suggests they belonged to two different sexes instead.<n>The research may also help scientists determine whether 'Sophie', the stegosaurus at the Natural History Museum in London really is a female or if it was in fact a male dinosaur.

Researchers from CNRS-GATE in Lyon and the University of California analysed the behaviour of both sexes.<n>They found that male 5,000 metre runners are more competitive than women.<n>This may explain why boys are often seen as being more competitive.<n>However, the researchers say that there can be a great deal of individual variability with some women actually showing greater competitive drive than most male athletes.<n>The study could have implications for other areas outside sport, such as in the workplace where greater gender diversity could bring advantages.

The gel contains platelet-rich plasma (PRP) - a concentrated mix of substances in the blood that play a role in healing.<n>It is made by taking a small amount of blood from a patient's arm and processing it in a machine that spins the blood at high speed until it separates into its various components.<n>Spinning the blood leaves behind the plasma and the platelets but in higher concentration - up to ten times greater than usual.<n>U.S. researchers are testing it as a dressing for burns.

Psychologists at New York University have been trying to gain an understanding about how the brain stores memories for 'emotionally neutral events'<n>They found people have better memory for boring information when it’s presented in an emotional context, regardless of if it is rewarding or negative.<n>Strong emotion can strengthen memory for positive events, such as a surprise birthday party thrown by close friends, and for negative events, such as making an embarrassing faux pas at the office holiday party.

The '#kyliejennerchallenge' is sweeping social media, encouraging teens to blow their lips up to epic proportions using bottles or shot glasses.<n>Participants place their mouth over the opening of a cup, jar or other narrow vessel and sucking in until the air vacuum causes their lips to swell up.<n>The method works by way of the airlock created in the opening of the glass or jar, which increases blood flow to the lips and causes them to swell.

WWF research identified 11 'deforestation fronts' where 80 per cent of projected global forest losses by 2030 could occur.<n>The areas are the Amazon, Atlantic Forest and Gran Chaco, and the Cerrado in South America, the Choco-Darien in Central America, the Congo Basin, East Africa, eastern Australia, the Greater Mekong in South East Asia, Borneo, New Guinea and Sumatra.<n>They are home to indigenous communities that depend on their livelihoods and endangered species such as orangutans and tigers.<n>But they are being lost to expanding agriculture, including livestock farming, palm oil plantations and soy production

A new exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York looks at the history of the city's Landmarks Law.<n>The law, which turns 50 on Sunday, protects historic buildings and places of cultural, architectural and historical significance.<n>The exhibition traces the trajectory of the preservation movement in New York City from the end of the 19th century up to the present day.<n>Famous buildings protected include Radio City Music Hall, St. Bartholomew's Church, Federal Hall, Brooklyn Botanic Garden, the New York Stock Exchange, Coney Island's Parachute Jump, and the Alice Austen House on Staten Island.

Swiss researchers measured the temperature of 'Hot Jupiter' HD 189733b.<n>They found the temperature reaches up to 3,000C in the atmosphere.<n>And wind speeds are in excess of 620mph (1,000km/h)<n>The findings were made using a novel technique relying on sodium signals.<n>And they suggest we may soon have the opportunity to examine other distant worlds beyond the solar system in unprecedented detail.

The United States' National Defense Reserve Fleet was set up in the wake of the Second World War.<n>At its peak in the 1950s, the fleet consisted of nearly 2,280 ships moored across the United States.<n>But as the need for the fleet has diminished, so has the number of vessels, and today, just over 120 ships remain.<n>Long years of neglect and disuse have turned the ships into near wrecks, with flaking paint polluting the waters.
Nasa scientists in California have revealed new images of the dwarf planet Ceres.<n>They reveal new views of the two brightest spots in a crater.<n>However, scientists are still not able to explain what they are.<n>Several theories currently exist for what they might be, with the favoured being salt flats or ice - both reflecting sunlight.<n>Dawn will begin its first science orbit around Ceres on 23 April.

Scientists at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory in Newport, Oregon, recorded underwater eruptions.<n>They found underwater volcanoes give off a muted thrum rather than the explosive roar emitted by their cousins on land.<n>Using their unique sound signature, researchers will be able to detect different types of eruptions and record the gases being released far more accurately.<n>Findings may mean models predicting how human activity will change the climate will need to be adjusted.

Research on infants’ brains by doctors from Oxford University found that young babies are more sensitive to pain than adults.<n>It overturns the medical consensus that newborns have a high pain threshold.<n>Up until the 1980s it was common practice for babies to go without pain relief during surgery - they were given neuromuscular blocks to stop them moving.<n>But injections are still given and intravenous drips still inserted without pain relief, and far more serious procedures carried out anything to take away the child’s pain.

'According to our work, information isn't lost once it enters a black hole,' says Dejan Stojkovic, an associate professor of physics at the University at Buffalo.<n>This is an important discovery because even physicists who believed information remains in black holes have struggled to show, mathematically, how this happens.<n>The research marks a significant step toward solving the 'information loss paradox,' a problem that has plagued physics for almost 40 years.

Researchers at John Hopkins Medical School in Baltimore have identified the area of the brain that is the key to picking up on when someone is being sarcastic.<n>They found people with damage to the right sagittal stratum - a bundle of white matter that lies between the cerebral cortex and subcortical structures in the brain - are unable to detect sarcasm.<n>Stroke patients with damage in the sagittal stratum in the right hemisphere of the brain were far poorer at detecting sarcasm when listening to sentences.

Comfortably Numb is a new, single-use device that eases the pain of an injection.<n>It produces a rapid chemical reaction to cool the patient's skin within 60 seconds.<n>A twisting motion moves the chambers into alignment to allow the chemicals to flow through the chamber to produce a rapid end reaction.<n>The skin can then be numbed by contacting the device's metal surface.<n>The team from Rice University in Houston said the device could be used in future for those having tattoos, or people wanting to get their ears pierced without suffering the pain.

Security researchers have discovered a way to intercept a person's fingerprints on a Samsung Galaxy S5 running Android 4.4 and older.<n>The vulnerability means that a hacker can access the kernel, or core, of the Android operating system.<n>Once inside they can monitor all data sent to and from the phone, as well as data recorded by the handset's built-in sensors, including the fingerprint scanner.<n>The flaw means that once a hacker has access they can monitor data recorded by built-in sensors, including the fingerprint scanner.<n>In April last year a group of German hackers managed to spoof the scanner

Burnt material, which includes approximately just over four ounces (118g) of cremated bone, was uncovered by Oxford Archaeology in Landford, Essex.<n>It was placed into a pit with a diameter of about three feet (one metre) and then backfilled with soil.<n>Three radiocarbon dates, two from bone fragments and one from charcoal, have confirmed the remains are around 7,614 years old.<n>The find is significant because it sheds light on early human society in Mesolithic Britain, when people were largely nomadic hunter gatherers.

A Colorado wastewater facility went up in flames on Friday after a fracking tanker was hit by lightning.<n>The fire began when lightning struck a water storage tank, launching it into the air.<n>The water contained traces of hydrocarbons and petroleum as a result of hydraulic fracturing, which ignited.<n>Firefighters had to wait for the explosion risk to subside so they could use fire suppression foam to extinguish the fire.<n>Nearby homes were evacuated, however no injuries were reported.

Researchers from the University of Patras took thermal infrared photographs of 41 volunteers’ faces, before and after drinking four glasses of wine.<n>They found the temperature of the forehead and nose is the best indication of a person’s drunken state and built an algorithm to recognise intoxication with 90% accuracy.<n>The technology could one day be installed in cars to spot drink drivers and stop them starting the ignition.

An Australian government report suggests that carbon dioxide produced by burning fossil fuels could be captured and used to produce the fizz in Cola.<n>Many nations are looking into Carbon Capture and Storage technologies as a way to cut their greenhouse house emissions.<n> CCS refers to the process of capturing carbon released by burning fossil fuels and storing it in porous rock layers in areas such as depleted oil and gas reservoirs.<n>The technology has the potential to reduce the emissions of a typical coal-power plant by up to 90 per cent.<n>But there are concerns over storing such huge amounts of carbon underground.

Grant 150 years ago on Thursday was a milestone event in the end of the Civil War.<n>Thursday's commemoration in Appomattox, Virginia, included a reenactment of Lee's last clash with Grant's troops and of the Confederate surrender in a Virginia farmhouse on April 9, 1865.<n>Ragged, hungry Southern soldiers, many straggling and on the run from federal forces, began giving up alone and in small bunches even before the official surrender.

Scientists at Stanford University School of Medicine have hailed their antibody injection a 'tour de force'<n>They believe it could eradicate melanoma, pancreatic, breast and lung cancer.<n>Process relies on the same mechanism as that which causes animals' bodies to reject organ transplants.<n>In both cases, antibodies - molecules that detect foreign substances in the body - trigger the immune system.<n>When T-cells come into contact with the 'unwelcome' tissue, they attack and destroy it.

Fossils from an extinct pygmy sperm whale that died seven million years ago have shed new light on the evolution of modern day whales.<n>The remains, which were discovered in Panama, indicate that the bone involved in sound generation and echolocation got smaller.<n>In contrast modern sperm whales are much larger than their extinct relatives.<n>The find will help experts fill in gaps in the evolution of cetaceans.

Molalla Log Cabin was made a historic landmark in 1991.<n>Historic building repairer Gregg Olson and architectural historian Pam Hayden have been analyzing the structure for seven years.<n>They believe it could have been built as early as 1795 - a decade before Lewis and Clark reached the Pacific Ocean.<n>The cabin's intricate construction is not consistent with pioneer building methods, suggesting it was created by foreigners.<n>The way the logs are tightly interwoven, secured without nails and leaving no gaps to fill, is similar to Russian log cabins of the same time period.

Researchers from Stanford University used data from 6,588 registered users to determine which colours are most commonly associated with which letters.<n>They then compared these colour-letter matches to fridge magnets sold by Fisher-Price between 1971 and 1990.<n>The results revealed that at least six per cent (400 out of the 6588 participants) learnt'many of their matches' from the Fisher-Price set.<n>Among those born in the decade after the toy began to be manufactured, the proportion of synesthetes with learned letter-colour pairings was closer to 15 per cent.

Last month, Nasa captured a 17 miles (27km) long iceberg being born in the West Antarctica's Getz Ice Shelf.<n>The image on the left shows the landscape before the iceberg broke three and on the right the monster berg floating in the ocean.<n>Measuring 17 miles (27km) long, iceberg B-34 appears to have fractured and moved out into the Amundsen Sea sometime in mid- to late-February 2015.<n>B-34 is the 34th iceberg from the 'B' quadrant of Antarctica to be tracked by the U.S. National Ice Center.
Monitoring by Hebridean Whale and Dolphin Trust teams has seen the number of encounters increase by 68 per cent over the past 12 years.<n>The dolphins come to the Hebrides in spring to take advantage of seasonal food stocks, travelling in large groups and sometimes forming ‘super-pods’ of thousands of individuals.<n>While they were once drawn to warmer waters above 10C south of the area, climate change is causing sea surface temperatures in the Hebrides to rise by around 0.5 C a decade.<n>And warmer water species appear to be colonising new areas further north or closer to shore,

Physicists at the University of Oregon used basic physics to model the force and torque required to place a pukao on a Moai’s head.<n>They concluded that the rounded oblong shape of the pukao means that it would have required relatively little energy to roll them up a ramp.<n>Some 1,000 carved Moai line the perimeter of the 12 mile (25km) volcanic island, which is the most isolated inhabited landmass on Earth.

Arizona, Texas, Montana, Missouri, and Oklahoma are the only five states in America that do not have texting at the wheel bans for all drivers.<n>Researchers from Texas A&M School of Public Health found that hospitalizations from car crashes dropped 7 percent between 2003 and 20010 in the 45 states with texting bans.<n>The greatest benefit was seen in states where texting bans are strictly enforced and where an officer can stop a car just on suspicion the driver breaking the law.

The biggest study of its kind suggests sex offending could run in the family along the male genetic line.<n>Researchers from the Karolinska Institute in Sweden found sons of fathers with a criminal record for sex offending were nearly four times more likely to be convicted.<n>Findings show 40 to 50 per cent of the differences in risk between close relatives of offenders and men from the general population were genetically driven.<n>But researchers stressed that this did not mean a man with a brother or father convicted of rape would inevitably follow in their footsteps.

The tech giant has bought Israel-based Link Computational Imaging.<n>LinX makes'multi-aperture' cameras small enough to fit into smartphones.<n>It could be added to the next-generation iPhones and iPads.<n>Unlike capturing a flat 2D image, the technology is able to sense the depth of each object in a photograph.<n>This lets people refocus an image after its been captured, or measure the dimensions of a room, for example.

Neanderthals and modern humans co-existed for thousands of years.<n>They interbred and are thought to have left Africa around 30,000 years ago.<n>Modern humans are thought to have brought diseases with them from Africa.<n>These include TB, typhoid, whooping cough, encephalitis and the common cold.<n>Neanderthals may have succumbed to these diseases as they migrated out of Africa.
The fossilised skeleton of Llallawavis scagliai was found in Argentina.<n>It is the most complete skeletons of a 'terror bird' to be discovered.<n>This is a group of flightless prehistoric meat-eating birds.<n>Scientists used 3D scanning of the long skull to examine its hearing ability.<n>They found it would have had an average hearing range of around 3,800Hz and a sensitivity of around 2,300Hz.<n>This suggests the bird would have been better at detecting lower frequency sounds than humans are.

Jonathan Keats, an experimental philosopher, hopes to capture 1,000 years of changes at a mountain range in Massachusetts with his'millennium camera'<n>The camera, which is made of cooper and allows light to enter through a tiny hole and change paint inside, will create one image that Keats says will display centuries of changes to the environment.<n>To capture the exposure, Keats adapted a Renaissance art technique by using rose madder, a sturdy, organic-based oil paint, applied directly to the copper in the back of the camera.

Keshwa Chaca spans the Apurimac River near Huinchiri, Peru, in the Province of Canas.<n>Local villagers rebuild the bridge each year using the same techniques as their Inca ancestors.<n>The ropes for the bridge are made from the 'ichu' grass, which is braided into rope for the bridge.<n>It takes three days to renew the Keshwa Chaca, and although it may look brittle, it has been proven to support the weight of 56 people standing across the walkway.

Research led by the University of Montana has found that eating fast food after a workout may be just as beneficial as dietary supplements.<n>During recovery periods between periods of exercise, it didn’t matter what food was eaten, the study found.<n>Performance remained the same after resting for several hours.<n>While levels of glycogen - used by muscles as ‘fuel’ - were actually slightly higher after fast food was eaten as a recovery food.

Photographer Jeffrey Milstein has shot a fascinating project documenting black boxes, shedding light on what happens to the devices after crashes.<n>Despite the name, the boxes are usually red to help rescuers spot them among the wreckage of crashed planes and helicopters.<n>Mr Milstein's work saw him gain access to air safety storage facilities where data recorders end up following an accident.<n>Black boxes record flight data as well as conversations in the cockpit, providing an insight into the final moments on board aircraft.

The Salt card is designed to end the tiresome task of manually unlocking a smartphone or tablet, by automatically making it come to life whenever the user is nearby.<n>It also locks devices again as soon as a user moves out of range at a distance of 10 feet (three metres)<n>It connects to an app on a user’s Android handset or iPhone via Bluetooth and also tells them if they have strayed too far from their wallet, where it is suggested the Salt card is stored.<n>The card costs $20 (£13) and can be ordered from the company’s website.

Scientists at Hebrew University of Jerusalem studied the movement of octopuses.<n>They found that the orientation of the creature's body and the crawling direction are controlled independently in the brain.<n>Octopuses are thought to have evolved from clam-like creatures in the mollusc family.<n>But as they lost their hard protective shell, they seem to have evolved to move far faster than other members of the mollusc family like slugs or snails.

Scientists at the University of Connecticut say we know how far away the source of a sound is by listening to the echoes it produces.<n>In a study they found that the reverberation of sound helps us locate the distance of, for example, a car passing round a bend or a person nearby.<n>The results suggest that, as a sound gets further away, our brains are able to work out the differences in its maximum and minimum volume.<n>Without amplitude modulation, for example in an anechoic (echo-free) room, a person can't tell how far away that noise is.

Playing video games may not only improve the ability to perform visual tasks, but also the learning ability for those skills, a study by Brown University in Rhode Island has claimed.<n>The research subjects were shown an on-screen texture of short lines - either vertical or horizontal - and were asked to spot anomalies.<n>Their responses were measured in milliseconds.<n> Gamers were shown to be more successful when learning both tasks than non-gamers.<n>But it was unresolved whether video games improve visual learning or whether good visual learners tend to play more video games.

20 stone flakes and anvils were found just west of Lake Turkana in Kenya.<n>If correct, the date of the stone tools is 700,000 years older than any others found previously.<n>It means that ancient human ancestors were creating tools hundreds of thousands of years before the appearance of the first'man'<n>Many experts have long believed that it was the use of stone tools by early species of Homo like Homo habilis and Homo erectus that helped set them apart.<n>But the latest discovery is the strongest evidence yet that these early humans did have ability to make and use tools rather than being primative creatures

The image was created by superimposing a blurry picture of Monroe over a picture of Albert Einstein drawn in fine lines.<n>Features with a high spatial frequency (Einstein) are only visible when viewing them close up.<n>Those with low spatial frequencies (Monroe) are only visible from further away.<n>This produces a single image which changes when the viewer moves closer or farther away from the screen.

A new documentary is about to blow the lid on the illegal organ trade that is now allegedly worth a staggering US$1 billion a year in China.<n>‘Human Harvest: China’s Organ Trafficking’ will show how researchers began to uncover the gory details.<n>They believe the organs come from members of the Falun Gong movement – a quasi-religious group with millions of followers, which is banned by the Chinese Government.<n>This despite the fact 10,000 organs are transplanted in China every year, yet there are only a tiny number of people on the official donor register.
Researchers from National Chung Hsing University in Taiwan studied the expression of a class of genes known to be associated with petal development.<n>They found that in mature orchid flowers, the expression pattern suggests two protein complexes, called the 'L' complex and the 'SP' complex, compete to promote the formation of the lip and standard petals.<n>Experts converted lips into petals in two orchid species by reducing the activity of the L complex using gene silencing.<n> Lips attract insect pollinators and serve as a landing platform for them, which is thought to have given orchids an evolutionary advantage over other flowers, by promoting reproduction.

The tiny copper coin is smaller than a penny and dates from the Iron Age.<n>It was found in silt after the River Avon burst its banks between Bristol and Bath.<n>On one side is a horse’s head, while the other bears the image of the goddess Tanit, the chief deity of Carthage.<n>Experts have dated the coin to between 300 BC and 264 BC and say it came from the Western Mediterranean - probably Sardinia or ancient Carthage.

Flashgap is free for iOS and Android and was created by Julian Kabab.<n>Before a night out, one user creates an event and becomes its host.<n>They can then add friends to the event at any point until it ends.<n>Photos and videos taken on the app disappear into a hidden album.<n>This album remains hidden until midday the day after the event.<n>Only people who attended the event can see the album, and users can only delete the photos they took themselves.
Lusitanian toadfish make five types of calls and males can even sing in choruses to attract mates.<n>The fish woo females with long, rhythmical noises that sound like boat whistles, which also act as a deterrent to love rivals.<n>Portuguese scientists discovered that the sounds made by Lusitanian toadfish indicate who they are, their motivation and information about their nest.<n>Water temperature, tide level, fish motivation and the level of social interactions affected most acoustic parameters.

Sonnenspeicher uses a lithium iron phosphate battery to store energy.<n>This energy is harvested during the day by solar panels fitted to a roof.<n>Any excess is stored for when the sun goes down.<n>Rather than selling this electricity to the grid, homeowners can use this stored supply to power their home until the sun rises again.<n>Sonnenspeicher features an intelligent management system that automatically controls the charging and discharging current.<n>It additionally has a Sleep mode that ensures the storage system never runs low and will automatically go into standby when its not being used to increase efficiency.<n>

Kendalia Halle was built more than 100 years ago by German immigrants, who through the latter half of the 19th century comprised more than 5 percent of the state's population.<n>It's one of an estimated 1,000 dance halls that sprung up around Texas in the 1800s, knitting together German, Czech, Polish and other immigrant communities.<n>About 400 such halls still stand — many unused and decaying — but only two traditional Texas dance halls continue to operate on nearly a daily basis.

Earth is constantly oscillating and creating a hum that has been likened to the ring of a bell.<n>As short waves near the surface they create weak microseismic waves, which combine with long waves on the ocean's floor to create the constant hum.<n>During March 2008 two large seismic events took place, but the largest hum coincided with a Johanna storm.<n>The storm generated waves with a peak period of 16 seconds that reached heights of 42ft (12.8 metres)<n>From this, the team could conclude the hum was caused by the storm, and not leftover from the seismic events.

Ogle-2014-BLG-0124Lb is half as massive as Jupiter and is 13,000 light-years away.<n>It was detected by the Spitzer Space Telescope and the Ogle Warsaw Telescope.<n>Planet was discovered using a technique known as microlensing.<n>This happens when one star happens to pass in front of another, and its gravity acts as a lens to magnify and brighten the more distant star's light.<n>Most of the planets we know about are around 10-100 times closer than Ogle-2014-BLG-0124.

Castello Baronale was built in the 12th century, by Pope Urban VIII's nephew, Cardinal Barberini, in 1541.<n>The fort remained in the family for 400 years, until it was sacked by Napoleon when he plundered the castle's gold.<n>It was handed back to the Barberini family when Napoleon was defeated, and remained in their family until 1993.<n>The castle incorporates nine en-suite bedrooms, along with a further 2 rooms in an adjacent apartment, a ballroom, various reception rooms, theatre room, library, gym and fitness area.

Scientists discovered a protein which helps boost the body’s immune system ten-fold, an astonishing effect which could help patients fight off cancers and viruses.<n>The protein promotes the production of immune cells called cytotoxic T-cells, which have the ability to detect cancerous cells, hunt them down, and destroy them.<n>In a chance discovery in mice, it was found that a previously unknown protein dramatically boosted the body’s number of T-cells.<n>A team led by Imperial College London has already applied to patent the therapy, which they say could be ready for human trials within three years.

The remains were discovered in 2010 in the El Mirn Cave in Cantabria, Spain.<n>They belonged to a 35- to 40-year-old woman who was buried 18,700 years ago.<n>Her teeth bore the remains of plant pollen, fungi and animals.<n> microscopic evidence that the woman had been eating sponge capped, bolete mushrooms and gilled mushrooms from the Agaric group.<n>The study provides the oldest evidence yet that mushrooms were eaten by early humans and helps to shed new light on the mysterious Red Lady.

The Red Lady's remains were found in the El Mirn Cave in Cantabria, Spain.<n>Radiocarbon dating suggests she was buried 18,700 years ago.<n>Her grave provides the first evidence of an ancient Magdalenian burial in the region and an engraved stone found near her remains appears to have been a makeshift tombstone.<n>But the reasons why the female was buried in such an elaborate tomb, close to an area where her peers would have lived day-to-day, continues to baffle archaeologists.

The mysterious ‘Antarctic BW29 signal was recorded near the Orkney Islands, South Shetland Islands, and Antarctic Peninsula by scientists.<n>Experts are sure the noise isn’t made by Arnoux's beaked whales or Cuvier's beaked whales, because the signal doesn’t match their songs.<n>But it could belong to a strap-toothed whale, a southern bottlenosed whale or a Gray’s beaked whale, according to the study.

This is according to a new study which claims the Kola fireball had a 'disturbingly similar' path to asteroid 2014 UR116.<n>Spotted on April 19 last year, researchers used camera footage to help recreate its trajectory and hunt down any remaining fragments.<n>They determined the fireball's path by studying its flight and the meteorite's final impact site, before creating a computer model based on those figures.<n>The computer model compared the orbit of Annama, a 1,100lb (500kg) rock, with the evolution of a dozen orbits of near-Earth asteroids.

The strange formation was photographed by amateur astronomer Gordon Ewen, and is a sun spot.<n>The photograph of the chick-like sun spot was taken using a telescope at the bottom of his garden in Letchworth, Hertfordshire.<n>They occur when a concentration of magnetic fields causes the surface temperature to reduce.<n>Sun spots range in size, from just 10 miles (16km) to 100,000 miles (160,000km) wide - big enough to be seen from Earth without a telescope.

'Kick and kill' strategy aims to eradicate the virus, by stimulating the immune system - the body's natural defence mechanism - with a vaccine.<n>The theory, developed by researchers at University College London, the University of Oxford and the University of North Carolina, is based on a single patient case study.<n>Study looked at a single 59-year-old man in London who was an 'elite controller' - meaning his immune system could control HIV for a long period of time without needing treatment.

Patients’ lives are at risk from blood poisoning because hospitals are not implementing a standard treatment, experts have warned.<n>Sepsis, previously known as septicaemia, affects more than 100,000 Britons a year and kills 37,000 – more than breast, bowel and prostate cancer combined.<n>A snapshot NHS study reveals 90 per cent of patients failed to get the correct treatment on a surgical ward at Edinburgh Royal Infirmary.<n>Sepsis Six involves blood tests to check for infection; testing the level of lactate, a chemical produced when cells are starved of oxygen; giving oxygen and IV fluids to protect organs and raise dangerously low blood pressure.

Mummified remains were found in the 18th century crypt of the Dominican church in Vc, Hungary.<n>Researchers from Warwick University isolated DNA of several strains of tuberculosis from the mummies.<n>They found eight of the 26 mummies showed signs that they had been infected with the disease, five of whom had suffered from multiple strains.<n>They traced the strains back to a single germ that began infecting people during the late Roman period.<n>It is the first evidence that mixed infections of multiple strains of TB were common in the 18th Century.

A lunar eclipse occurs when the moon passes through the edge of the earth's shadow.<n>This is an area known as the umbra, where light from the sun is blocked by our planet.<n>The light refracts differently in the atmosphere and, as it hits the moon, it makes it appear red.<n>A lunar eclipse is the third in a series of four blood moons, with the final one expected on September 28.

It was previously thought that the woolly mammoth died out from post-Ice Age climate change and being hunted to extinction by early man.<n>But a new theory is set to re-write the history books after the examination of more than 23,500 mammoth bones found them riddled with osteoporosis.<n>Deficiency in calcium resulted in mammoths breaking their limbs and spines.<n>In turn it meant the giant animal, which stood 10ft (three metres) high, eventually collapsed to the ground and could not forage for food, or flee hunters.

First comprehensive picture of how neurons connect to one another found local networks of neurons layered like the shells in a Russian nesting doll.<n>Two local networks governing vision and learning, and another tapped into bodily concerns like muscle and organ function make up the inner shell of the rat's cerebral cortex.<n>Two others — one governing smell, and another that assembles and makes sense of the information from the other three networks — make up the outer shell.

Loeb has filed a lawsuit in California in a bid to prevent the Modern Family actress from destroying two cryopreserved female embryos created through IVF, according to InTouch.<n>Court documents detail how the couple fertilized embryos using her eggs and his sperm six months before their split in November 2013.<n> Loeb, 39, is seeking to ensure the female embryos are not destroyed, but Vergara has refused to 'agree to their preservation under all circumstances,' according to the legal papers.<n>Elsewhere in the lawsuit, it is claimed 42-year-old actress Vergara was 'physically and mentally abusive' to Loeb.
Experts studied 40 million posts by 1.7 millions users on CNN.com, Breitbart.com and gaming site IGN.com.<n>The researchers then divided users into those most likely to be banned, called Future-Banned Users (FBUs) and other users dubbed Never-Banned Users (NBUs)<n>The algorithm can recognise a potential troll with an accuracy of 80 per cent by scanning their comments.

Hans-Wilhelm Muller-Wohlfahrt quit Bayern Munich on Thursday.<n>The 72-year-old claimed 'the bond of trust is damaged' after defeat by Porto.<n>Pep Guardiola has denied a rift with the former club doctor.<n>Muller-Wohlfahrt had worked at Bayern for almost 40 years.
Chelsea beat Stoke City 2-1 in their Premier League clash on Saturday.<n>Cesc Fabregas was caught in the face by Charlie Adam's flailing arm.<n>The Spain international was left with a nasty-looking gash on his nose.
Tony Pulis is weighing up the possibility of signing Nice forward Alassane Plea.<n>The former Lyon trainee has been capped at various levels by France.<n>Pulis remains confident of keeping hold of star striker Saido Berahino.
England hooker Tom Youngs was sin-binned for a barge on Chris Ashton.<n>Saracens scored two tries with him off and the game was as good over at 14-6 when he came back.<n>Tigers director of rugby Richard Cockerill said: 'If you block a bloke you are going to get penalised and probably go to the bin'<n>Billy Vunipola scored after Youngs' exit and Marcelo Bosch scored after the break.
Shaun Andrew McKerry, 31, burst into Shildon Post Office and Stores.<n>He waved an axe as he demanded cash from terrified assistant.<n>But he did not see owner Sab Dhillon's rugby tackle which dropped him.<n>As the men wrestled, Mr Dhillon's wife Sam hit McKerry with a baseball bat.<n>She struck him twice, helping to disarm him while her husband twisted him.<n>As the men wrestled, and with McKerry still holding the axe, Mr Dhillon's wife Sam helped, hitting him twice with a baseball bat to make him drop the weapon.
Bishop Robert Finn pleaded guilty in 2012 to failing to report suspected abuse.<n>He waited six months before alerting police about Reverand Shawn Ratigan.<n>Ratigan was eventually sentenced to 50 years in prison after pleading guilty to child pornography charges.<n>It has made Finn the highest-ranking church official in the U.S. to be convicted of failing to take action in response to abuse allegations.<n>Children's rights advocates are urging Pope Francis to do much more to deal with clergy who become embroiled in child sex scandals.
Hydrogen-fuel is appealing for use in cars, but producing hydrogen requires huge amounts of energy.<n>With the new breakthrough, it could be possible to make it more easily.<n>Researchers at the University of Bath and Yale University created the invention.<n>It uses a newly designed molecular catalyst to split water in an electrolyser and create clean and storable hydrogen fuel.<n>This technology could store energy as hydrogen, which can then be used on demand.
Newcastle United lost 3-1 at home to Tottenham Hotspur last weekend.<n>Thousands of fans boycotted the match in protest at owner Mike Ashley.<n>Fans group AshleyOut.com are encouraging supporters to 'Stand Up To Ashley' when Swansea visit St James' Park on Saturday.<n>This will involve a 34th-minute protest in recognition of the £34million which was last week revealed to be sitting in the club's bank.
Peter Morris was devastated when his sister, Claire, died in a car crash.<n>He believed she had died in a tragic accident in Aberdeen, Scotland, in 1994.<n>It took two decades for the truth to be revealed - she had been murdered.<n>Claire's story was turned into an ITV drama starring Sheridan Smith.
